question: In patients with systemic lupus erythematosus, does a Th2-dominant immune environment inhibit disease activity and the development of lupus nephritis? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: We report that activation of basophils by autoreactive IgE causes their homing to lymph nodes, promoting T helper type 2 (T(H)2) cell differentiation and enhancing the production of self-reactive antibodies that cause lupus-like nephritis in mice lacking the Src family protein tyrosine kinase Lyn (Lyn(-/-) mice).
content.source_2: In a longitudinal SLE cohort, elevations of serum IgE, self-reactive IgEs, and activation markers on basophils (CD62L and HLA-DR) were independently associated with decreased global disease activity and a lower incidence of lupus nephritis, consistent with a disease-impeding Th2 milieu.
content.source_3: In Lyn-deficient mice, Th2-skewed basophil and IgE responses curtailed autoantibody expansion and prevented progression to nephritis; paralleling this, SLE patients with higher IgE and basophil activation exhibited lower disease activity scores and fewer renal flares.
